rules.htmlContent:
Modifications of parts. Parts may NOT be modified unless specifically listed as an exception in this rule. Examples of illegal modifications include, but are not limited to, bending, cutting, sanding, gluing, lubricating, taping, and melting. The following exceptions are the only legal modifications of parts:
• Cutting metal VEX IQ or VEX V5 shafts to custom lengths.
• Bending parts which are intended to be flexible, such as string, rubber bands, or thin plastic sheets.
• Cutting VEX IQ pneumatic tubing to custom lengths.
• Tying knots to shorten or connect string or rubber bands.

rules.title: Robot and Field setup for Robot Skills Matches
rules.description: Robot and Field setup for Skills Matches
rules.htmlContent:
Robot and Field setup for Skills Matches. The Robot and Field are set up the same as a Teamwork Challenge Match, with the following modifications:
• The layout of Scoring Objects for a Mix & Match Robot Skills Match differs from the layout for Teamwork Challenge Matches, as shown in Figure RSC3-1. Pins and Beams start in different locations on the Field. The Robot receives one red Pin as a Preload. Six Pins (two red, two blue, and two orange) begin the Match in the Red Driver Station for Loading.
• The blue Load Zone is not used in Robot Skills Matches. Scoring Objects of any color may be introduced into the red Load Zone only. This includes any Scoring Object that is reintroduced after leaving the Field during the Match.
• The Robot must be placed in contact with the structure of the red Triangle Goal at the beginning of the Match and after the Robot is reset under rule <GG10> or <RSC5>.


Figure RSC3-1: The Field Configuration for a VIQRC Mix and Match Robot Skills Match.

rules.title: Loader and Driver differences
rules.description: Loader and Driver differences
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Loader and Driver differences.{{/BOLD}} All criteria listed in <SG6> apply as written (e.g., a Loader cannot put a {{ITALIC}}Scoring Object{{/ITALIC}} into a {{ITALIC}}Load Zone{{/ITALIC}} if there’s already a {{ITALIC}}Scoring Object{{/ITALIC}} there). {{ITALIC}}Loading{{/ITALIC}} is modified as follows: 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}In both {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}, any {{ITALIC}}Driver{{/ITALIC}} who is not currently Driving the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} may also serve as a Loader (i.e., a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} may have one, two, or three Loaders at any given time). 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}The blue {{ITALIC}}Load Zone{{/ITALIC}} is not used in {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}, and {{ITALIC}}Scoring Objects{{/ITALIC}} may only be introduced into the red {{ITALIC}}Load Zone{{/ITALIC}}. This includes any {{ITALIC}}Scoring Object{{/ITALIC}} that is reintroduced after leaving the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} during the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Any {{ITALIC}}Scoring Object{{/ITALIC}} that leaves the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} during a {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} should be given to the {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} human Loader for reintroduction at the red {{ITALIC}}Load Zone{{/ITALIC}}, regardless of that object’s color. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} must remain in the red {{ITALIC}}Driver Station{{/ITALIC}} during {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}, except when legally interacting with their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} per rule <GG10>.

rules.htmlContent:
Loader and Driver differences. All criteria listed in <SG6> apply as written (e.g., a Loader cannot put a Scoring Object into a Load Zone if there’s already a Scoring Object there). Loading is modified as follows:
• In both Driving Skills Matches and Autonomous Coding Skills Matches, any Driver who is not currently Driving the Robot may also serve as a Loader (i.e., a Team may have one, two, or three Loaders at any given time).
• The blue Load Zone is not used in Robot Skills Matches, and Scoring Objects may only be introduced into the red Load Zone. This includes any Scoring Object that is reintroduced after leaving the Field during the Match.
• Any Scoring Object that leaves the Field during a Robot Skills Match should be given to the Team’s human Loader for reintroduction at the red Load Zone, regardless of that object’s color.
• Drive Team Members must remain in the red Driver Station during Driving Skills Matches, except when legally interacting with their Robot per rule <GG10>.

rules.title: Handling Robots during an Autonomous Coding Skills Match
rules.description: Handling Robots during an Autonomous Coding Skills Match
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Handling Robots during an Autonomous Coding Skills Match.{{/BOLD}} A {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} may handle their {{ITALIC}}{{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}{{/ITALIC}} as many times as desired during an {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Upon handling the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}, it must be immediately brought back to a legal starting position. {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} may reset or adjust the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} as desired from this position, including pressing buttons on the Robot Brain or activating sensors. Any {{ITALIC}}Scoring Objects{{/ITALIC}} being controlled by the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} while being handled must be removed from the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}}, and can be reintroduced by a Loader in accordance with <SG6> and <RSC4>. In the context of this rule, “controlled” implies that the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} was manipulating the {{ITALIC}}Scoring Object{{/ITALIC}}, and not simply touching it. For example, if the {{ITALIC}}Scoring Object{{/ITALIC}} would move with the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} either vertically or while turning, then the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} is “controlling” that {{ITALIC}}Scoring Object{{/ITALIC}}. As described in rule <S1>, {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} cannot step into the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} at any time during a {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. If the {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} cannot reach the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} due to the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} being in the center of the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}}, they may ask the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} to pick up the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} and hand it to the {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} for placement according to the conditions above. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}During an {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}}, {{ITALIC}}Drivers{{/ITALIC}} may move freely around the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}}, and are not restricted to the {{ITALIC}}Driver Station{{/ITALIC}} when not handling their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}. The rest of <GG1>, which states that {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} are not allowed to use any communication devices during their {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}, still applies. An intent of this exception is to permit {{ITALIC}}Drivers{{/ITALIC}} who wish to “stage” {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} handling during an {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} to do so without excessive running back and forth to the {{ITALIC}}Driver Station{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{CALLOUT}}This rule is an explicit exception to rules <GG4> and the Violation Note for <GG10>, and may be used as part of a {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} strategy for {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} are still governed by <GG4> & the Violation Note for <GG10>, especially for strategic {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}}.{{/CALLOUT}}

{{CALLOUT}}This rule is an explicit exception to rules <GG4> and the Violation Note for <GG10>, and may be used as part of a {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} strategy for {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} are still governed by <GG4> & the Violation Note for <GG10>, especially for strategic {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}}.{{/CALLOUT}}
rules.htmlContent:
Handling Robots during an Autonomous Coding Skills Match. A Team may handle their Robot as many times as desired during an Autonomous Coding Skills Match.
• Upon handling the Robot, it must be immediately brought back to a legal starting position. Drive Team Members may reset or adjust the Robot as desired from this position, including pressing buttons on the Robot Brain or activating sensors. Any Scoring Objects being controlled by the Robot while being handled must be removed from the Field, and can be reintroduced by a Loader in accordance with <SG6> and <RSC4>. In the context of this rule, “controlled” implies that the Robot was manipulating the Scoring Object, and not simply touching it. For example, if the Scoring Object would move with the Robot either vertically or while turning, then the Robot is “controlling” that Scoring Object. As described in rule <S1>, Students cannot step into the Field at any time during a Match. If the Drive Team Members cannot reach the Robot due to the Robot being in the center of the Field, they may ask the Head Referee to pick up the Robot and hand it to the Drive Team Members for placement according to the conditions above.
• During an Autonomous Coding Skills Match, Drivers may move freely around the Field, and are not restricted to the Driver Station when not handling their Robot. The rest of <GG1>, which states that Drive Team Members are not allowed to use any communication devices during their Match, still applies. An intent of this exception is to permit Drivers who wish to “stage” Robot handling during an Autonomous Coding Skills Match to do so without excessive running back and forth to the Driver Station.
This rule is an explicit exception to rules <GG4> and the Violation Note for <GG10>, and may be used as part of a Team’s strategy for Autonomous Coding Skills Matches. Driving Skills Matches are still governed by <GG4> & the Violation Note for <GG10>, especially for strategic Violations.

rules.title: Starting an Autonomous Coding Skills Match
rules.description: Starting an Autonomous Coding Skills Match
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Starting an Autonomous Coding Skills Match.{{/BOLD}} {{ITALIC}}Drivers{{/ITALIC}} must start a {{ITALIC}}Robot’s{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} routine by pressing a button on the Robot Brain or manually activating a sensor. Because there is no VEX IQ Controller hand-off, only one (1) {{ITALIC}}Driver{{/ITALIC}} is required for an {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} (though {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} may still have two (2) if desired). 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Pre-{{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} sensor calibration is considered part of the standard pre-{{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} setup time (i.e., the time when the {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} would typically be turning on the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}, moving any mechanisms to their desired legal start position, etc.). 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Pressing a button on the VEX IQ Controller to begin the routine is not permitted. To avoid any confusion, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are advised not to bring controllers to {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{CALLOUT}}In accordance with <GG3>, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} should be mindful of event schedules and set their {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} up as promptly as possible. The definition of “prompt” is at the discretion of the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}, and could depend on things like how much time is left for the Skills Challenge {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}}(s) to be open, how many {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are waiting in line, etc. As a general guideline, three seconds to calibrate a Gyro Sensor would be acceptable, but three minutes to debug a program would not.{{/CALLOUT}}

rules.htmlContent:
Starting an Autonomous Coding Skills Match. Drivers must start a Robot’s Autonomous Coding Skills Match routine by pressing a button on the Robot Brain or manually activating a sensor. Because there is no VEX IQ Controller hand-off, only one (1) Driver is required for an Autonomous Coding Skills Match (though Teams may still have two (2) if desired).
• Pre-Match sensor calibration is considered part of the standard pre-Match setup time (i.e., the time when the Team would typically be turning on the Robot, moving any mechanisms to their desired legal start position, etc.).
• Pressing a button on the VEX IQ Controller to begin the routine is not permitted. To avoid any confusion, Teams are advised not to bring controllers to Autonomous Coding Skills Matches.
In accordance with <GG3>, Teams should be mindful of event schedules and set their Robot up as promptly as possible. The definition of “prompt” is at the discretion of the Event Partner and Head Referee, and could depend on things like how much time is left for the Skills Challenge Field(s) to be open, how many Teams are waiting in line, etc. As a general guideline, three seconds to calibrate a Gyro Sensor would be acceptable, but three minutes to debug a program would not.

rules.title: Autonomous means "no humans"
rules.description: Autonomous means “no humans
rules.fullText: {{BOLD}}Autonomous means “no humans.”{{/BOLD}} During an {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}}, {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} are not permitted to activate any controls on their VEX IQ Controller, and cannot manually trigger sensors (including the Vision Sensor) in any way, even without touching them.

rules.title: Skills Stop Time
rules.description: Skills Stop Time
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Skills Stop Time.{{/BOLD}} If a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} wishes to end their {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} early, they may elect to record a {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Time{{/ITALIC}}. This is used as a tiebreaker for {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Challenge{{/ITALIC}} rankings. A {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} does not affect a {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} score for a given {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Match{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Drivers{{/ITALIC}} and field staff must agree prior to the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} on the signal that will be used to end the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} early. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}As noted in the definition of {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Time{{/ITALIC}}, the moment when the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} ends early is defined as the moment when the {{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Scoring Objects{{/ITALIC}} have come to a rest and the {{ITALIC}}Driver{{/ITALIC}} provides the agreed upon visual and audio signal to the {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referee{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} who intend to attempt a {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} must “opt-in” by verbally confirming with the {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referee{{/ITALIC}} prior to the {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Match{{/ITALIC}}. If no notification is given prior to the start of the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}, then the {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} forfeits their option to record a {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} for that {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}This conversation should include informing the {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referee{{/ITALIC}} which {{ITALIC}}Driver{{/ITALIC}} will signal the stop. The {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} may only be ended early by a {{ITALIC}}Driver{{/ITALIC}} for that {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}The agreed-upon signal to stop the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} must be both verbal and visual, such as {{ITALIC}}Drivers{{/ITALIC}} crossing their arms in an “X” or placing their VEX IQ Controller on the ground. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}It is recommended that the {{ITALIC}}Driver{{/ITALIC}} also provides a verbal notice that they are approaching their {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Time{{/ITALIC}}, such as counting out “3-2-1-stop.” 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}If a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} runs multiple {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} in a row, they must reconfirm their {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} choice with the {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referee{{/ITALIC}} prior to each {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Any questions regarding a {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} should be reviewed and settled immediately following the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. <T1> and <T3> apply to Robot Skills Matches.

rules.htmlContent:
Skills Stop Time. If a Team wishes to end their Robot Skills Match early, they may elect to record a Skills Stop Time. This is used as a tiebreaker for Robot Skills Challenge rankings. A Skills Stop Time does not affect a Team’s score for a given Robot Skills Match. Drivers and field staff must agree prior to the Match on the signal that will be used to end the Match early.
• As noted in the definition of Skills Stop Time, the moment when the Match ends early is defined as the moment when the Robot and Scoring Objects have come to a rest and the Driver provides the agreed upon visual and audio signal to the Scorekeeper Referee.
• Teams who intend to attempt a Skills Stop Time must “opt-in” by verbally confirming with the Scorekeeper Referee prior to the Robot Skills Match. If no notification is given prior to the start of the Match, then the Team forfeits their option to record a Skills Stop Time for that Match.
• This conversation should include informing the Scorekeeper Referee which Driver will signal the stop. The Match may only be ended early by a Driver for that Match.
• The agreed-upon signal to stop the Match must be both verbal and visual, such as Drivers crossing their arms in an “X” or placing their VEX IQ Controller on the ground.
• It is recommended that the Driver also provides a verbal notice that they are approaching their Skills Stop Time, such as counting out “3-2-1-stop.”
• If a Team runs multiple Robot Skills Matches in a row, they must reconfirm their Skills Stop Time choice with the Scorekeeper Referee prior to each Match.
• Any questions regarding a Skills Stop Time should be reviewed and settled immediately following the Match. <T1> and <T3> apply to Robot Skills Matches.

rules.title: The Head Referee has final authority on all gameplay and Robot ruling decisions
rules.description: Head Referees have ultimate and final authority on all gameplay and robot ruling decisions during the competition
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Head Referees have ultimate and final authority on all gameplay and robot ruling decisions during the competition.{{/BOLD}} 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referees{{/ITALIC}} score the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}, and may serve as observers or advisers for the {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}}, but may not determine any {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}} directly. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}When issuing a {{ITALIC}}Disqualification{{/ITALIC}} or {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} to a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}}, the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} should attempt to notify the {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} as the {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} occurs, and after the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} must provide the rule number of the specific rule that has been Violated and record the {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} in the Match Anomaly Log. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}CoC-related Violations{{/ITALIC}} require additional escalation beyond the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee’s{{/ITALIC}} initial ruling, including (but not limited to) investigation by RECF representatives. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Event Partners{{/ITALIC}} may not overrule a {{ITALIC}}Head Referee’s{{/ITALIC}} gameplay or {{ITALIC}}{{ITALIC}}Robot{{/ITALIC}}{{/ITALIC}} decisions. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Every {{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}} must be watched by a certified {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}} may only watch one {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} at a time; if multiple {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}} are happening simultaneously on separate {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}}, each {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} must have its own {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}} must follow the rules in this game manual and the Q&A, and must make rulings consistent with the intent of the game manual and Q&A. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}At a minimum, every {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} must be watched by a trained {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referee{{/ITALIC}}, who may only watch one {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} at a time. If multiple {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} are happening simultaneously on separate {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}}, each {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} must have its own {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referee{{/ITALIC}}. A certified {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} must be available at the event to explain a rule, {{ITALIC}}Disqualification{{/ITALIC}}, {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}}, or other penalty to {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} in {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} as needed in support of the {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referees{{/ITALIC}} at skills {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{CALLOUT}}Note from the VEX GDC: The rules contained in this Game Manual are written to be enforced by human {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}}. Many rules have “black-and-white” criteria that can be easily checked. However, some rulings will rely on a judgment call from this human {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}. In these cases, {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}} will make their calls based on what they and the {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referees{{/ITALIC}} saw, what guidance is provided by their official support materials (the Game Manual and the Q&A), and most crucially, the context of the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} in question. The VEX IQ Robotics Competition does not have video replay, our {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} do not have absolute sensors to count scores, and most events do not have the resources for an extensive review conference between each {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. When an ambiguous rule results in a controversial call, there is a natural instinct to wonder what the “right” ruling “should have been,” or what the GDC “would have ruled.” This is ultimately an irrelevant question; our answer is that when a rule specifies “{{ITALIC}}Head Referee’s {{/ITALIC}}discretion” (or similar), then the “right” call is the one made by the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} in the moment. The VEX GDC designs games, and writes rules, with this expectation (constraint) in mind.{{/CALLOUT}}

rules.htmlContent:
Head Referees have ultimate and final authority on all gameplay and robot ruling decisions during the competition.
• Scorekeeper Referees score the Match, and may serve as observers or advisers for the Head Referees, but may not determine any Violations directly.
• When issuing a Disqualification or Violation to a Team, the Head Referee should attempt to notify the Team as the Violation occurs, and after the Match must provide the rule number of the specific rule that has been Violated and record the Violation in the Match Anomaly Log.
• CoC-related Violations require additional escalation beyond the Head Referee’s initial ruling, including (but not limited to) investigation by RECF representatives.
• Event Partners may not overrule a Head Referee’s gameplay or Robot decisions.
• Every Qualification Match and Finals Match must be watched by a certified Head Referee. Head Referees may only watch one Match at a time; if multiple Matches are happening simultaneously on separate Fields, each Field must have its own Head Referee. Head Referees must follow the rules in this game manual and the Q&A, and must make rulings consistent with the intent of the game manual and Q&A.
• At a minimum, every Robot Skills Match must be watched by a trained Scorekeeper Referee, who may only watch one Match at a time. If multiple Robot Skills Matches are happening simultaneously on separate Fields, each Field must have its own Scorekeeper Referee. A certified Head Referee must be available at the event to explain a rule, Disqualification, Violation, or other penalty to Teams in Robot Skills Matches as needed in support of the Scorekeeper Referees at skills Fields.
Note from the VEX GDC: The rules contained in this Game Manual are written to be enforced by human Head Referees. Many rules have “black-and-white” criteria that can be easily checked. However, some rulings will rely on a judgment call from this human Head Referee. In these cases, Head Referees will make their calls based on what they and the Scorekeeper Referees saw, what guidance is provided by their official support materials (the Game Manual and the Q&A), and most crucially, the context of the Match in question. The VEX IQ Robotics Competition does not have video replay, our Fields do not have absolute sensors to count scores, and most events do not have the resources for an extensive review conference between each Match. When an ambiguous rule results in a controversial call, there is a natural instinct to wonder what the “right” ruling “should have been,” or what the GDC “would have ruled.” This is ultimately an irrelevant question; our answer is that when a rule specifies “Head Referee’s discretion” (or similar), then the “right” call is the one made by the Head Referee in the moment. The VEX GDC designs games, and writes rules, with this expectation (constraint) in mind.

rules.title: Head Referees must be qualified
rules.description: Head Referees must be qualified
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Head Referees must be qualified.{{/BOLD}} VEX IQ {{ITALIC}}Head Referees {{/ITALIC}}must have all of the following qualifications: 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Be at least 16 years of age. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Be approved by the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Be an REC Foundation Certified VIQRC {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} for the current season. Visit the REC Library for more details. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Cannot be the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} or a Judge Advisor for the event. Note: {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referees{{/ITALIC}} must be at least 15 years of age, and must be approved by the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner.{{/ITALIC}}

rules.htmlContent:
Head Referees must be qualified. VEX IQ Head Referees must have all of the following qualifications:
• Be at least 16 years of age.
• Be approved by the Event Partner.
• Be an REC Foundation Certified VIQRC Head Referee for the current season. Visit the REC Library for more details.
• Cannot be the Event Partner or a Judge Advisor for the event. Note: Scorekeeper Referees must be at least 15 years of age, and must be approved by the Event Partner.

rules.title: Drive Team Members are permitted to immediately appeal the Head Referee's ruling
rules.description: The Drive Team Members are permitted to immediately appeal the Head Referee’s ruling
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}The Drive Team Members are permitted to immediately appeal the Head Referee’s ruling.{{/BOLD}} If {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} wish to dispute a score or ruling, they must stay in the {{ITALIC}}Driver Station{{/ITALIC}} until the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} talks with them. The {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} may choose to meet with the {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} at another location and/or at a later time so that the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} has time to reference materials or resources to help with the decision. Once the {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}} announces that their decision has been made final, the issue is over and no more appeals may be made (see rule <T1>). 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Referees are not permitted to review any photo or video {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} recordings when determining a score or ruling. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}} are the only individuals permitted to explain a rule, {{ITALIC}}Disqualification{{/ITALIC}}, or {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} to the {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} in a {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} should never consult other field personnel, including {{ITALIC}}Scorekeeper Referees{{/ITALIC}}, regarding a ruling clarification. Communication and conflict resolution skills are an important life skill for {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} to practice and learn. In VEX IQ Robotics Competitions, we expect {{ITALIC}}Students{{/ITALIC}} to practice proper conflict resolution using the proper chain of command. {{ITALIC}}Violations{{/ITALIC}} of this rule may be considered a {{ITALIC}}Violation{{/ITALIC}} of <G1> and/or the Code of Conduct. 
{{CALLOUT}}Some events may choose to utilize a “question box” or other designated location for discussions with {{ITALIC}}Head Referees{{/ITALIC}}. Offering a “question box” is within the discretion of the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} and/or {{ITALIC}}Head Referee{{/ITALIC}}, and may act as an alternate option for asking {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} to remain in the {{ITALIC}}Driver Station{{/ITALIC}} (although all other aspects of this rule apply). However, by using this alternate location, {{ITALIC}}Drive Team Members{{/ITALIC}} acknowledge that they are forfeiting the opportunity to use any contextual information involving the specific state of the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} at the end of the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}. rules.title: The Event Partner have final authority regarding all non-gameplay decisions
rules.description: The Event Partner has ultimate authority regarding all non-gameplay decisions during an event
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}The Event Partner has ultimate authority regarding all non-gameplay decisions during an event.{{/BOLD}} The Game Manual is intended to provide a set of rules for successfully playing VIQRC Mix & Match; it is not intended to be an exhaustive compilation of guidelines for running a VEX IQ Robotics Competition event. Rules such as, but not limited to, the following examples are at the discretion of the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} and should be treated with the same respect as the Game Manual: 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Venue access 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Pit spaces 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Health and safety 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} registration and/or competition eligibility 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} conduct away from competition {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} 
{{CALLOUT}}This rule exists alongside <G1>, <S1>, and <G3>. Even though there isn’t a rule that says “do not steal from the concession stand,” it would still be within an {{ITALIC}}Event Partner’s{{/ITALIC}} authority to remove a thief from the competition.{{/CALLOUT}}

rules.htmlContent:
The Event Partner has ultimate authority regarding all non-gameplay decisions during an event. The Game Manual is intended to provide a set of rules for successfully playing VIQRC Mix & Match; it is not intended to be an exhaustive compilation of guidelines for running a VEX IQ Robotics Competition event. Rules such as, but not limited to, the following examples are at the discretion of the Event Partner and should be treated with the same respect as the Game Manual:
• Venue access
• Pit spaces
• Health and safety
• Team registration and/or competition eligibility
• Team conduct away from competition Fields
This rule exists alongside <G1>, <S1>, and <G3>. Even though there isn’t a rule that says “do not steal from the concession stand,” it would still be within an Event Partner’s authority to remove a thief from the competition.

rules.title: Be prepared for minor Field variance
rules.description: Be prepared for minor field variance
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Be prepared for minor field variance.{{/BOLD}} {{ITALIC}}Field Element{{/ITALIC}} tolerances may vary from nominal by up to ±0.5” [12.7mm], unless otherwise specified. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are encouraged to design their {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}} accordingly. Please make sure to check Appendix A for more specific nominal dimensions and tolerances. 
{{CALLOUT}}The {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Field Elements{{/ITALIC}} are designed to be assembled and disassembled multiple times each year. {{ITALIC}}Event Partners{{/ITALIC}} store and transport {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} between events, and the individuals setting up the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} at one event may differ from those at the next. While every effort will be made to ensure minimal variance, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} should expect that any {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} may be slightly different than another, and prepare accordingly. Just because something works on one {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} does not fully guarantee it will work on the next, and is not enough evidence alone to determine if a {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} is out of tolerance.{{/CALLOUT}}

rules.htmlContent:
Be prepared for minor field variance. Field Element tolerances may vary from nominal by up to ±0.5” [12.7mm], unless otherwise specified. Teams are encouraged to design their Robots accordingly. Please make sure to check Appendix A for more specific nominal dimensions and tolerances.
The Field and Field Elements are designed to be assembled and disassembled multiple times each year. Event Partners store and transport Fields between events, and the individuals setting up the Field at one event may differ from those at the next. While every effort will be made to ensure minimal variance, Teams should expect that any Field may be slightly different than another, and prepare accordingly. Just because something works on one Field does not fully guarantee it will work on the next, and is not enough evidence alone to determine if a Field is out of tolerance.

rules.title: Fields and Field Elements may be repaired at the Event Partner's discretion
rules.description: Fields and Field Elements may be repaired at the Event Partner’s discretion
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Fields and Field Elements may be repaired at the Event Partner’s discretion.{{/BOLD}} All competition {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} and other {{ITALIC}}Field Elements{{/ITALIC}} at an event must be set up in accordance with the specifications in Appendix A and/or other applicable support materials. Minor aesthetic customizations or repairs are permitted, provided that they do not impact gameplay (see <T4>). Examples of permissible modifications include, but are not limited to: 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Replacing a damaged or missing VEX IQ component with an identical part of any color. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Elevating the playing {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} off of the {{ITALIC}}Floor{{/ITALIC}} (common heights are 10” to 24” [254mm to 609.6mm]). 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Using off-the-shelf PVC to replace a damaged or missing pipe. 

{{BOLD}}Significant Q&As{{/BOLD}}: 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{LINK:/VIQRC/2025-2026/QA/2801}}Q&A 2801{{/LINK}} - Accommodation requests for color-blindness and marked Pins

All competition Fields and other Field Elements at an event must be set up in accordance with the specifications in Appendix A and/or other applicable support materials. Minor aesthetic customizations or repairs are permitted, provided that they do not impact gameplay (see <T4>). Examples of permissible modifications include, but are not limited to:

rules.title: Fields at an event must be consistent with each other
rules.description: Fields at an event must be consistent with each other
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Fields at an event must be consistent with each other.{{/BOLD}} There are many types of permissible aesthetic and/or logistical modifications that may be made to competition {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} at the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner’s{{/ITALIC}} discretion. If an event has multiple {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}}, they must all incorporate the same permissible/applicable modifications. If an event has multiple Robot Skills Challenge {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}}, they must all incorporate the same permissible/applicable modifications. For example, if one {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} is elevated, then all {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}{{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}}{{/ITALIC}} must be elevated to the same height. Examples of these modifications may include, but are not limited to: 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Elevating the playing {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} off of the {{ITALIC}}Floor{{/ITALIC}} (common heights are 12” to 24” [30.5cm to 61cm]) 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Field display monitors 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Field Perimeter{{/ITALIC}} decorations (e.g., LED lights, sponsor banners attached to risers) Note: If an event has dedicated {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} for {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}, there is no requirement for them to have the same consistent modifications as the {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}}. See <T16> for more details.

rules.htmlContent:
Fields at an event must be consistent with each other. There are many types of permissible aesthetic and/or logistical modifications that may be made to competition Fields at the Event Partner’s discretion. If an event has multiple Teamwork Challenge Fields, they must all incorporate the same permissible/applicable modifications. If an event has multiple Robot Skills Challenge Fields, they must all incorporate the same permissible/applicable modifications. For example, if one Field is elevated, then all Teamwork Challenge Fields must be elevated to the same height. Examples of these modifications may include, but are not limited to:
• Elevating the playing Field off of the Floor (common heights are 12” to 24” [30.5cm to 61cm])
• Field display monitors
• Field Perimeter decorations (e.g., LED lights, sponsor banners attached to risers) Note: If an event has dedicated Fields for Robot Skills Matches, there is no requirement for them to have the same consistent modifications as the Teamwork Challenge Fields. See <T16> for more details.

rules.title: Qualification Matches will occur according to the official Match schedule
rules.description: Qualification Matches will occur according to the official match schedule
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Qualification Matches will occur according to the official match schedule.{{/BOLD}} This schedule will indicate {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} partners, {{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}} times, and, if the event has multiple {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}}, which {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} each {{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}} will be played on. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Practice Matches{{/ITALIC}} may be included in the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} schedule at some events, but are not required. If {{ITALIC}}Practice Matches {{/ITALIC}}are run, every effort will be made to equalize practice time for all {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}A {{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}} can only start before its scheduled time if all {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}}, {{ITALIC}}Robots{{/ITALIC}}, and assigned volunteers are at the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} and ready to play. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Any multi-division event must be approved by the REC Foundation RSM prior to the event, and divisions must be assigned in sequential order by {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} number. Note: The official {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} schedule is subject to changes at the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner’s{{/ITALIC}} discretion.

rules.htmlContent:
Qualification Matches will occur according to the official match schedule. This schedule will indicate Alliance partners, Qualification Match times, and, if the event has multiple Fields, which Field each Qualification Match will be played on.
• Practice Matches may be included in the Match schedule at some events, but are not required. If Practice Matches are run, every effort will be made to equalize practice time for all Teams.
• A Qualification Match can only start before its scheduled time if all Teams, Robots, and assigned volunteers are at the Field and ready to play.
• Any multi-division event must be approved by the REC Foundation RSM prior to the event, and divisions must be assigned in sequential order by Team number. Note: The official Match schedule is subject to changes at the Event Partner’s discretion.

rules.title: Each Team will be scheduled Qualification Matches as follows
rules.description: Each Team will be scheduled Qualification Matches as follows
rules.htmlContent:
Each Team will be scheduled Qualification Matches as follows.
• When in a tournament, the tournament must have a minimum of six (6) Qualification Matches per Team at local qualifying events and eight (8) for a Championship event.
• When in a league, there must be at least three (3) league ranking sessions, with at least one (1) week between sessions. Each session must have a minimum of two (2) Qualification Matches per Team. The suggested number of Qualification Matches per Team for a standard league ranking session is four (4). Event Partners may choose to have Qualification Matches as part of their league finals session.

rules.title: Teams are ranked by their average Qualification Match scores
rules.description: Teams are ranked by their average Qualification Match scores
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Teams are ranked by their average Qualification Match scores.{{/BOLD}} 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}When in a tournament, every {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} will be ranked based on the same number of {{ITALIC}}Qualification Matches{{/ITALIC}}. For tournaments that have more than one (1) division, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} will be ranked among all {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} in their specific division. Each division will have its own set of {{ITALIC}}Finals Matches{{/ITALIC}}. The winners of each division will then have an overall event Finals. Any multi-division event must be approved by the REC Foundation Regional Support Manager prior to the event, and divisions must be assigned in sequential order by {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} number. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}When in a league, every {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} will be ranked based on the number of {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}} played. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} that participate in less than 60% of the total {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}} available will be ranked below {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} that participate in at least 60% of the total {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}} available (e.g., if the league offers 3 ranking sessions with 4 {{ITALIC}}Qualification Matches{{/ITALIC}} per {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}}, {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} that participate in 8 or more {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}} will be ranked higher than {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} who participate in 7 or fewer {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}}). Being a no-show to a {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} that a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} is scheduled in still constitutes participation for these calculations. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}A certain number of a {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} lowest {{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}} scores will be excluded from the rankings based on the quantity of {{ITALIC}}Qualification Matches{{/ITALIC}} each {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} plays. Excluded scores do not affect participation for leagues. “No show” {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}}, as described in <GG2>, are not considered lowest scores for the purposes of calculating a {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}} ranking and will never be excluded from the calculation. 

{{TABLE}}
Number of {{ITALIC}}Qualification Matches{{/ITALIC}} per {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} | Number of excluded {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} scores
-----------------------------------------+--------------------------------
4-7                                      | 1                              
8-11                                     | 2                              
12-15                                    | 3                              
16+                                      | 4                              
{{/TABLE}}

 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}In some cases, a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} will be asked to play an additional {{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}}. The extra {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} will be identified on the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} schedule with an asterisk and will not impact the {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} ranking (or participation for leagues). {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are reminded that <G1> is always in effect and {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are expected to behave as if the additional {{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}} counted.

The extra {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} will be identified on the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} schedule with an asterisk and will not impact the {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} ranking (or participation for leagues). {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are reminded that <G1> is always in effect and {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are expected to behave as if the additional {{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}} counted.
rules.htmlContent:
Teams are ranked by their average Qualification Match scores.
• When in a tournament, every Team will be ranked based on the same number of Qualification Matches. For tournaments that have more than one (1) division, Teams will be ranked among all Teams in their specific division. Each division will have its own set of Finals Matches. The winners of each division will then have an overall event Finals. Any multi-division event must be approved by the REC Foundation Regional Support Manager prior to the event, and divisions must be assigned in sequential order by Team number.
• When in a league, every Team will be ranked based on the number of Matches played. Teams that participate in less than 60% of the total Matches available will be ranked below Teams that participate in at least 60% of the total Matches available (e.g., if the league offers 3 ranking sessions with 4 Qualification Matches per Team, Teams that participate in 8 or more Matches will be ranked higher than Teams who participate in 7 or fewer Matches). Being a no-show to a Match that a Team is scheduled in still constitutes participation for these calculations.
• A certain number of a Team’s lowest Qualification Match scores will be excluded from the rankings based on the quantity of Qualification Matches each Team plays. Excluded scores do not affect participation for leagues. “No show” Matches, as described in <GG2>, are not considered lowest scores for the purposes of calculating a Team’s Qualification Match ranking and will never be excluded from the calculation.

• In some cases, a Team will be asked to play an additional Qualification Match. The extra Match will be identified on the Match schedule with an asterisk and will not impact the Team’s ranking (or participation for leagues). Teams are reminded that <G1> is always in effect and Teams are expected to behave as if the additional Qualification Match counted.

rules.title: Qualification Match tiebreakers
rules.description: Qualification Match tiebreakers
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Qualification Match tiebreakers.{{/BOLD}} {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} rankings are determined throughout {{ITALIC}}Qualification Matches{{/ITALIC}} by: 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Removing the {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} lowest score and comparing the new average score. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Removing the {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} next lowest score and comparing the new average score (on through all scores). 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}If the {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} are still tied, the {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} will be sorted by random electronic draw.

rules.htmlContent:
Qualification Match tiebreakers. Team rankings are determined throughout Qualification Matches by:
• Removing the Team’s lowest score and comparing the new average score.
• Removing the Team’s next lowest score and comparing the new average score (on through all scores).
• If the Teams are still tied, the Teams will be sorted by random electronic draw.

rules.title: How Alliances are formed for Teamwork Challenge Matches
rules.description: How Alliances are formed for Teamwork Matches
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}How Alliances are formed for Teamwork Matches.{{/BOLD}} During each {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}, two (2) {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} form an {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} that will play on the {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Qualification Match{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Alliances{{/ITALIC}} are randomly assigned by the tournament software. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Alliances{{/ITALIC}} are assigned as follows based on {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}}’ rankings after all {{ITALIC}}Qualification Matches{{/ITALIC}} have concluded (see <T10>): The first- and second-ranked {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} form an {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}}. The third- and fourth-ranked {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} form an {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}}. And so on, until all {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} participating in {{ITALIC}}Finals Matches{{/ITALIC}} have formed an {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}}.

rules.htmlContent:
How Alliances are formed for Teamwork Matches. During each Teamwork Challenge Match, two (2) Teams form an Alliance that will play on the Field.
• Qualification Match Alliances are randomly assigned by the tournament software.
• Finals Match Alliances are assigned as follows based on Teams’ rankings after all Qualification Matches have concluded (see <T10>): The first- and second-ranked Teams form an Alliance. The third- and fourth-ranked Teams form an Alliance. And so on, until all Teams participating in Finals Matches have formed an Alliance.

Events that qualify teams directly to the VEX Robotics World Championship must have a minimum of five (5) {{ITALIC}}Finals Matches{{/ITALIC}} if there are ten (10) or more {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} in attendance.

Events that qualify teams directly to the VEX Robotics World Championship must have a minimum of five (5) Finals Matches if there are ten (10) or more Teams in attendance.

rules.title: Finals Match schedule
rules.description: Finals Match Schedule
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Finals Match Schedule.{{/BOLD}} {{ITALIC}}Finals Matches{{/ITALIC}} are played sequentially, starting with the lowest-ranked {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}}. Each {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} will participate in one (1) {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}}. The {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} with the highest {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}} score is the {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} champion. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Alliances{{/ITALIC}} are ranked by their {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}} score. The highest-scoring {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} is in first place, the second-highest-scoring {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} is in second place, etc. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Ties for first place will result in a series of tiebreaker {{ITALIC}}Finals Matches{{/ITALIC}}, starting with the lower-seeded {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}}. The {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} with the highest tiebreaker {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}} score will be declared the {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} champion. If the tiebreaker {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}} scores are tied, the {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} with the higher {{ITALIC}}Match Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} will be declared the winner. If the {{ITALIC}}Match Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} is also tied, a second series of tiebreaker {{ITALIC}}Finals Matches{{/ITALIC}} will be played. If this second series of tiebreaker {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}} is also tied, then the higher-seeded {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} will be declared the winner. If there is a tie for a place other than first, the higher-seeded {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} will receive the higher rank. 
{{CALLOUT}}Example 1: {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 6 and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 3 are tied for first place. During the tiebreaker {{ITALIC}}Finals Match{{/ITALIC}}, {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 6 scores 13 points and has a {{ITALIC}}Match Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} of 12 seconds. {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 3 scores 13 points and has a {{ITALIC}}Match Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} of 10 seconds. {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 6 is the {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} winner. Example 2: {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 4 and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 5 are tied for third place. {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 4 is the third place winner and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 5 is the fourth place winner. In this way, the lower ranked {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} must “overcome” the higher ranked {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} in order to become the {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} champion.{{/CALLOUT}}

Example 2: {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 4 and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 5 are tied for third place. {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 4 is the third place winner and {{ITALIC}}Alliance{{/ITALIC}} 5 is the fourth place winner. rules.htmlContent:
Finals Match Schedule. Finals Matches are played sequentially, starting with the lowest-ranked Alliance. Each Alliance will participate in one (1) Finals Match. The Alliance with the highest Finals Match score is the Teamwork Challenge champion.
• Alliances are ranked by their Finals Match score. The highest-scoring Alliance is in first place, the second-highest-scoring Alliance is in second place, etc.
• Ties for first place will result in a series of tiebreaker Finals Matches, starting with the lower-seeded Alliance. The Alliance with the highest tiebreaker Finals Match score will be declared the Teamwork Challenge champion. If the tiebreaker Finals Match scores are tied, the Alliance with the higher Match Stop Time will be declared the winner. If the Match Stop Time is also tied, a second series of tiebreaker Finals Matches will be played. If this second series of tiebreaker Finals Match is also tied, then the higher-seeded Alliance will be declared the winner. If there is a tie for a place other than first, the higher-seeded Alliance will receive the higher rank.
Example 1: Alliance 6 and Alliance 3 are tied for first place. During the tiebreaker Finals Match, Alliance 6 scores 13 points and has a Match Stop Time of 12 seconds. Alliance 3 scores 13 points and has a Match Stop Time of 10 seconds. Alliance 6 is the Teamwork Challenge winner. Example 2: Alliance 4 and Alliance 5 are tied for third place. Alliance 4 is the third place winner and Alliance 5 is the fourth place winner. In this way, the lower ranked Alliance must “overcome” the higher ranked Alliance in order to become the Teamwork Challenge champion.

rules.title: Robot Skills Match schedule
rules.description: Skills Match Schedule
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Skills Match Schedule.{{/BOLD}} {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} play {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} on a first-come, first-served basis. Each {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} will get the opportunity to play exactly three (3) {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} and three (3) {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} should review the event agenda and their {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} schedule to determine when the best possible time is to complete their {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}. If the {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Challenge{{/ITALIC}} area closes before a {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} has completed all six (6) {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}, but it is determined that there was adequate time given, then the {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} will automatically forfeit those unused {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}}. Details regarding logistics of Skills-Only Events can be found in the REC Foundation Qualifying Criteria document. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} are only available to {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} who participate in {{ITALIC}}Qualification Matches{{/ITALIC}}, unless the event is an approved Skills-Only Event. {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} who participate in {{ITALIC}}Qualification Matches{{/ITALIC}} during a specific League Ranking Session are the only {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} who can participate in {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}} at that session. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Skills scores recorded by ineligible {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} will be deleted from Tournament Manager before the event is finalized on RobotEvents.com.

rules.htmlContent:
Skills Match Schedule. Teams play Robot Skills Matches on a first-come, first-served basis. Each Team will get the opportunity to play exactly three (3) Driving Skills Matches and three (3) Autonomous Coding Skills Matches. Teams should review the event agenda and their Match schedule to determine when the best possible time is to complete their Robot Skills Matches. If the Robot Skills Challenge area closes before a Team has completed all six (6) Robot Skills Matches, but it is determined that there was adequate time given, then the Team will automatically forfeit those unused Matches. Details regarding logistics of Skills-Only Events can be found in the REC Foundation Qualifying Criteria document.
• Robot Skills Matches are only available to Teams who participate in Qualification Matches, unless the event is an approved Skills-Only Event. Teams who participate in Qualification Matches during a specific League Ranking Session are the only Teams who can participate in Robot Skills Matches at that session.
• Skills scores recorded by ineligible Teams will be deleted from Tournament Manager before the event is finalized on RobotEvents.com.

rules.title: No requirement that Skills Fields have the same modifications as Teamwork Fields
rules.description: There is no requirement that Skills Challenge fields have the same consistent modifications as the Teamwork fields
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}There is no requirement that Skills Challenge fields have the same consistent modifications as the Teamwork fields.{{/BOLD}} For example, there is no requirement that {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} are elevated to the same height as {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}}. In order to use non-conforming {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} for {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}} (e.g. during lunch), the following steps should be taken: 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} must be informed that the {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} may have some differences from the {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Fields{{/ITALIC}} (e.g., they might be elevated). 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}{{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} must be given an opportunity to select which type of {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} they want to use, i.e. they cannot be required to use a {{ITALIC}}Teamwork Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Field{{/ITALIC}} for any {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Challenge{{/ITALIC}} {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}.

rules.htmlContent:
There is no requirement that Skills Challenge fields have the same consistent modifications as the Teamwork fields. For example, there is no requirement that Robot Skills Challenge Fields are elevated to the same height as Teamwork Challenge Match Fields. In order to use non-conforming Teamwork Challenge Fields for Robot Skills Challenge Matches (e.g. during lunch), the following steps should be taken:
• Teams must be informed that the Teamwork Challenge Fields may have some differences from the Robot Skills Challenge Fields (e.g., they might be elevated).
• Teams must be given an opportunity to select which type of Field they want to use, i.e. they cannot be required to use a Teamwork Challenge Field for any Robot Skills Challenge Match.

rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Skills Rankings at events.{{/BOLD}} {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} will be ranked at an event based on the following scores and tiebreakers: 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Sum of highest {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} score and highest {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} Score. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Highest {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} score. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Second-highest {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} score. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Second-highest {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} score. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Highest sum of {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Times{{/ITALIC}} from a {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} highest {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} and highest {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} (i.e., the {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}} in point 1). 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Highest {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Time{{/ITALIC}} from a {{ITALIC}}Team’s{{/ITALIC}} highest Autonomous Coding Skills Match (i.e., the {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}} in point 2). 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Third-highest {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} score 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}Third-highest {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} score. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}If the tie cannot be broken after all above criteria (i.e., both {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} have the exact same scores and {{ITALIC}}Skills Stop Times{{/ITALIC}} for each {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Match{{/ITALIC}}), then the following ordered criteria will be used to determine which {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} had the “best” {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}}: Points for {{ITALIC}}Stacks{{/ITALIC}} in the {{ITALIC}}Standoff Goal{{/ITALIC}} Points from {{ITALIC}}Matching Goal{{/ITALIC}} Bonus Points for 2-color and 3-color {{ITALIC}}Stacks{{/ITALIC}} 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}If the tie still cannot be broken, the same process in the step above will be applied to the {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}}’ highest {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Matches{{/ITALIC}}. 
{{BOLD}}• {{/BOLD}}If the tie still isn’t broken, the {{ITALIC}}Event Partner{{/ITALIC}} may choose to allow {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} to have one more deciding {{ITALIC}}Match{{/ITALIC}}, or both {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} may be declared the winner.

Skills Rankings at events. Teams will be ranked at an event based on the following scores and tiebreakers:
• Sum of highest Autonomous Coding Skills Match score and highest Driving Skills Match Score.
• Highest Autonomous Coding Skills Match score.
• Second-highest Autonomous Coding Skills Match score.
• Second-highest Driving Skills Match score.
• Highest sum of Skills Stop Times from a Team’s highest Autonomous Coding Skills Match and highest Driving Skills Match (i.e., the Matches in point 1).
• Highest Skills Stop Time from a Team’s highest Autonomous Coding Skills Match (i.e., the Match in point 2).
• Third-highest Autonomous Coding Skills Match score
• Third-highest Driving Skills Match score.
• If the tie cannot be broken after all above criteria (i.e., both Teams have the exact same scores and Skills Stop Times for each Autonomous Coding Skills Match and Driving Skills Match), then the following ordered criteria will be used to determine which Team had the “best” Autonomous Coding Skills Match: Points for Stacks in the Standoff Goal Points from Matching Goal Bonus Points for 2-color and 3-color Stacks
• If the tie still cannot be broken, the same process in the step above will be applied to the Teams’ highest Driving Skills Matches.
• If the tie still isn’t broken, the Event Partner may choose to allow Teams to have one more deciding Match, or both Teams may be declared the winner.

rules.htmlContent:
Skills Rankings globally. Teams are ranked based on their Robot Skills scores from Tournaments and Leagues that upload results to RobotEvents.com, according to the following tiebreakers.
• Highest Robot Skills score (combined Autonomous Coding Skills Match and Driving Skills Match Score from a single event).
• Highest Autonomous Coding Skills Match score (from any event).
• Highest sum of Skills Stop Times from the Robot Skills Matches used for point 1.
• Highest Skills Stop Time from the Autonomous Coding Skills Match used for point 2.
• Highest Driving Skills Match score (from any event).
• Highest Skills Stop Time from the Driving Skills Match score used in point 5.
• Earliest posting of the highest Autonomous Coding Skills Match score. The first Team to post a score ranks ahead of other Teams that post the same score at a later time, all else being equal.
• Earliest posting of the highest Driving Skills Match score. The first Team to post a score ranks ahead of other Teams that post the same score at a later time, all else being equal.

rules.title: Robot Skills at league events
rules.description: Robot Skills at League Events
rules.fullText:
{{BOLD}}Robot Skills at League Events.{{/BOLD}} At league events in which {{ITALIC}}Teams{{/ITALIC}} may submit {{ITALIC}}Robot Skills Challenge{{/ITALIC}} scores across multiple sessions, the Robot Skills scores (combined highest {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} and {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} scores) used for rankings will be calculated from {{ITALIC}}Matches{{/ITALIC}} within the same session. For example, consider the following scores for a hypothetical {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} across two league event sessions: 

{{TABLE}}
          | {{ITALIC}}Autonomous Coding Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} | {{ITALIC}}Driving Skills Match{{/ITALIC}} | Robot Skills Score
----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+-------------------
Session 1 | 25                             | 45                   | 70                
Session 2 | 30                             | 42                   | 72                
{{/TABLE}}

 This {{ITALIC}}Team{{/ITALIC}} would have a Robot Skills score of 72 for this event’s rankings, and their scores from Session 2 would be used for the event and global tiebreakers listed in <T17> and <T18>.
